text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We also sort of know what side effects you’re going to experience to sort of see whether you can tolerate this. We have to adjust the doses about that. So that’s an approved drug that’s known to extend survival if people get the drugs, tolerate the drugs, respond to the drugs. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know those people can do well compared to those who don’t respond or don’t get the drug. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So chemo would be something that you know it could be given here, it could be given there, but it’s standard treatment. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a clinical trial where we’re giving the chemotherapy and everybody gets an infusion two to three times a week. So- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: for someone coming from F___ may it may be too much to come in here that often, but we’re giving Vitamin C to half the people and half the people don’t because some data says that Vitamin C may reduce the side effects of the chemotherapy and also help the benefit. text: Patient: It’s not bad is it? Doctor: I mean I don’t think it’s worse, but it’s not getting better. Family Member: So would that lesion affect his legs also, is it the same stem you know nerve system? Doctor: You know usually not. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Because I mean hopefully – the arm nerves are on the outside. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay so the leg nerves are running further down. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But I mean technically yes, if there is a clean total cut of the cord or major pressure at that level, it can affect the arms and the legs. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Because I have pain walking upstairs. Doctor: Sort of the Christopher Reeve’s spot –

text: Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Okay? And you have the desire, uh, but there may be a point where I think you maybe too sick or your labs don’t work, or there are other things that suggest that more therapy is not the right thing. Patient: I see. Doctor: I will say that to you. It may not be what you want to hear. Patient: It’s the reality. (Pause) Doctor: As long as the quality’s good. That’s my worry. Okay? You can get extra time, but if it sucks, then it’s (not awful) Patient: Yeah. (Pause) Doctor: Well, you folks let’s do this, okay? I -- I’m gonna put the prescription into the pharmacy here, and they’re gonna start checking as to how much it’s gonna cost you. You may say that we don’t have a prescription plan or it’s too expensive, and I can’t do it for that reason. It may be that we get through that and the door’s still open for the study because you can afford it and we can get started. Okay? But you guys have to talk about it as a family. You’ve got the paperwork to read. You can go through it, discuss it. You know, okay, this would mean that we’re gonna have to commit to going down to Baltimore every other week this time, do some more bloodwork. These are the things that I worry about. Yeah, we’re all good for that. Okay? Because you’re not on the study until you meet again with us, that your PSA is rising on the enzalutamide Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have to get the enzalutamide started (Pause) Patient: Okay. Okay. Lemme just, so the enzalutamide, the Xtandi, okay. Doctor: That’s all we’re going to start now, and you have to get worse on it to be able to be eligible for the study. (Pause15sec)

text: Patient: I stopped doing that quite a while ago. Family Member 1: Yeah, that's what he said about a couple of weeks ago. He stopped. He's giving her separated. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Okay, now, M_____'s pregnant, she picked up his water and drank the whole water the other day by accident. I don't know. Doctor: That's okay. Yeah, I think where when you're on chemo, you have to use universal precautions, you know. So it's always easier if you have more than one bathroom in your home. So that even if you have your own bathroom space where your towels and you can have Lysol and things. You feel comfortable. That's just his bathroom, so that you don't always constantly have to Lysol and Clorox things. Patient: Right. Doctor: If you have only one bathroom you'll just be very diligent you'll get some gloves you wipe down after you use the bathroom with because chemo- Family Member: With what? Doctor: Oh with Lysol Clorox anything over the counter you got the wipes. They all work. Family Member 1: Wipes work? Flush twice? Doctor: Yep flush twice and then with the wipes put them in the garbage, but just keep it separate. Patient: Right.

text: Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and you know, depending on what your scans show, I actually would favor Provenge, which is the vaccine therapy, because it’s almost like a flu shot. We don’t really know what happens to the PSA but we do know that if you get it in people who get it Patient: Is that a shot or is that through? Doctor: So, here’s where it gets a little complicated. You know, the flu shot is also like a vaccine. That, you know, you just get here. But, in cancer it’s a little bit more complicated. So, what we would do is actually send you to the Red Cross right across the street. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They hook you up to a machine and then they take out your cells so they’re not using my cells or anybody else’s cells. They’re taking out your cells, your immune cells so that when they take it they ship it to Atlanta so if you’ve never been to Atlanta, your cells will be. They wake it up and then they ship it back to me, the like better version of you and then I reinfuse it back to you so that your cells know to find the cancer. That’s the thought of how that medicine works. So, we do that, let’s say the Red Cross on a Monday, I get your stuff back like on a Thursday and then I reinfuse it to you on a Thursday. We do that 3 times and then the treatment is done. It’s self-limited. Okay. Patient: So, that’s your immune system. Doctor: That’s the immune system. Patient: So, what happens in between, does that weaken your immune system or? Doctor: No, it actually if anything strengthens. Patient: I mean while it’s out. Doctor: Oh, no. We don’t take everything out. We just take a few things out. Patient: Oh, okay.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: What else? Patient: And for how long does this study last? Doctor: As long as you respond, we keep going. So if you are side effects, or too much, or you're like, Listen, I'm just done, we stop. If you say my gosh, this thing is really good. And I'm doing great, we keep going. And it's we can't take the drug away from you. Sometimes that's to the irritation of the pharma company, because sometimes they want to get out after a year, but it's actually interesting. One of my other studies, somebody's been on two years longer than they thought, and they want to close it. And we're like, well, I'm sorry, my one guy's doing great. So you can't take it away from us. So there's that other option, but in general, it's you who calls it quits or that the cancer’s has moved on. And if that's happened, we got to stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Mhm. Patient: Cancer. The cancer subsided or it can't reverse cancer get worse. Doctor: The cancer has gotten worse and moved on to new spots or new areas. Oh, you know, it's not gonna be shy. It'll tell us. Yeah. So at this moment is just sort of the slow creep, you know, it’s the- What do you mean? It's six right? I mean, you haven't way in the beginning you were near 300 there but you've always been super low. So when we look at you, it's like this tiny little rises but nothing that's like this. Yeah, Patient: Just a quick note- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - it started out much higher than that. I think you get Doctor: Yeah, no, no, I had you correct. Yeah, we met each other after your stuff started but in our system, that's as high as you been?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
